@Lokota_Rain OK. Best of luck to you
@Lokota_Rain why do you think they use toys? BECAUSE THEY ARE PREY DRIVEN TO CHASE IT.
@Lokota_Rain dogs bred for high genetic prey drive i.e police dogs for detection work couldn't be further from that
@Lokota_Rain but most of the ones I deal with are.
@Lokota_Rain a dog so driven to chase a prey object that nothing reward wise you can offer is more enticing. Again few dogs are like this
@Lokota_Rain marker training and body language is the backbone to communicating with a dog in my "so called" trainer opinion
@Lokota_Rain I believe most people cause pain stress and fear without realizing it. I believe in using as many tools as possible to achieve
@Lokota_Rain dog exhibiting self reward that can't be trumped by anything you can offer. Very few dogs have that kind of drive-but some do
@Lokota_Rain correctly or incorrectly. To say "I don't believe in using X" says to me you don't know how to properly utilize that tool
@Lokota_Rain remember reward and punishment is in the eye of the beholder - just like with people. All equipment are tools that can be used
@Lokota_Rain I believe in predominant +R learning for sure
column4: but I also think again every dog is different and some need +p

text: @Lokota_Rain we agree on that- and that's my point is that every dog is different and making that blanket statement is a hard way to start
@Lokota_Rain I think every dog/handler is different and there is no blanket answer. It's a starting point that I think gets over complicated
@Lokota_Rain it's simple math. Adding and subtracting reinforcement/punishment to get desired results.
@Lokota_Rain http://t.co/Tzf9C7vGFv
@Lokota_Rain you are incorrect - positive and negative mean adding and subtracting. For both reinforcement and punishment -Not bad and good
@Lokota_Rain and -R completely depends on what the R is. Blanket statements like that show inflexibility in my view
@Lokota_Rain negative reinforcement is withholding the reward. That was in response to your "not jumping up and getting loved or get nothing
@Lokota_Rain I can only say the same thing so many times- visual cue is what
column4: reinforcing is why.

text: @Lokota_Rain are you actually reading anything I'm posting?
@Lokota_Rain again- making my point. The visual cue you speak of doesn't communicate any of that. It's simply the pretext
@Lokota_Rain you're making my point. Why being the "fun" is the positive reinforcement. Not the visual cue you give the dog
@Lokota_Rain thought about it - and there's not a behavior a dog can do that you can't extinguish through negative reinforcement
@Lokota_Rain appear to have disappeared? What does disappear mean? To not appear - so if a dog doesn't do it then it's irrelevant if he
@Lokota_Rain point frame of reference for a beginner to understand. Have you actually read the book or just listened to one interview?
@Lokota_Rain its on a book on how to start to train. So me stating an over simplification of how we comm vs. how dogs comm is a starting
@Lokota_Rain agreed- but that's still not the why. You've taught what it means but not why they are supposed to. And in ref to the interview
@Lokota_Rain to test that theory - stop regarding the dog after the cue and watch behavior disappear. If it was why- it wouldn't
@Lokota_Rain I understand that- but a cue means only what. Not why. Reward based on what motivates the dog is not part of that equation.
@Lokota_Rain ok-but your visual cue doesn't tell the dog why - it simply says "to" - reward or punishment is the why
@Lokota_Rain I disagree 100%. I always prefer dog offering behavior on its own and it being marked and reinforced. Self discovery > cueing
@Lokota_Rain there's a big difference between a "man" and adult male
@Lokota_Rain but to that point - exactly.  Visual cues don't communicate a reason as to why do it now instead of later. Reinforcement does
@Lokota_Rain A "man" doesn't need to be asked
@Lokota_Rain from my perspective of what I've seen its a humans lack of understanding how to communicate what we want. Hence my wording
@Lokota_Rain my point was simply that they learn very differently than we do. Trying to get humans to see the world from dog perspective
@Lokota_Rain it's in comparison to the other senses in which they use to communicate - in relation to the contrast in how we communicate
